{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3127049,"name":"Danny","username":"hage-043","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/hage-043/{size}/177637_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-15T22:59:00.565Z","cooked":"

Help!!! My team and I have been banging our heads against the wall for two entire work days trying to run our swerve chassis bot with mk4i neos. We were able to get 3 of the 4 modules working nicely last week, and then without having changed anything code or wiring wise, the modules now sputter as soon as we enable.

Note: the led on the spark max blinks blue (as it should) when disabled, and then when we enable it looks like the led isn’t getting enough power and it starts to sputter blue. It’s weird that the steer motor is trying to turn but the spark max doesn’t go to red or green.

Things we have tried:

  1. We ran the spark max from usb-c connection and encountered the same sputter behavior (aka. ruled out any issues coming from code)
  2. Checked all wiring 5 times
  3. Swapped motors and spark maxes
  4. Changed the PDP for a brand new PDH

Given that we have tried all of these things, can we safely assume that this is a battery issue? We have tried every battery in our shop, granted, they weren’t charging for months until two days ago.

Also, the batter chargers we have were the cheapest things we could find off Amazon a couple of years ago. Does this type of problem indicate that we should a) invest in the real pro battery chargers from AndyMark? b) always be charging our batteries

Does the status light look like any of these? Status LED Patterns - SPARK MAX

Also, do you have a battery beak to get a battery status, or a simple volt meter to check battery voltage?

Yes! We do in fact have a battery beak with a slightly dented screen. Five of the batteries we tested read “good” with greater than 100% charge and over 13V. However, after retrying the same battery on the battery beak sometimes the status would drop to fair but then go back to good. After installing the Rev PDH, the battery would read 12.0V on the led screen, and say 12.7V or so on driver station.

With regards to the status lights, the spark max looks like it’s trying to be cyan, as expected, but the best way to describe it is a flicker.

There is not flickering (just blinking) when the robot is simply disabled.

I’m not much of an electrical guy, so this is a bit of a shoot in the dark, but have you tried swapping the main breaker?

UPDATE:

We have now ruled out any battery issue. At this point our main suspicion is that after upgrading to the Spark Max’s to firmware 1.6.2, something happened. We have encountered the same issue over and over again with all of our motors. We tested the amperage and resistance of both the motors and motor controllers and determined that there was extremely low current flowing from the steer motor’s Spark Max while it was trying to turn to its setpoint (0.1 - 0.3 amps). Has anyone encountered similar issues with this new firmware? We have the latest vendor dependencies for our code and are fairly confident it is not a code issue. We have also tried downgrading to 1.6.1 and 1.5.2 but that process continually bugs out which is a whole other issue.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2023-01-18T22:35:45.894Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":93,"readers_count":92,"score":28.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":423315,"topic_slug":"spark-max-neo-glitch","display_username":"Danny","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51704,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/spark-max-neo-glitch/423315/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3129323,"name":"dyanoshak","username":"dyanoshak","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dyanoshak/{size}/65422_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-18T23:06:43.805Z","cooked":"

If you haven’t already, please reach out to us at support@revrobotics.com. Video of what you are seeing will be helpful for our team to try and recreate what you’re seeing.

I’ve seen flickering of the status LEDs happen when there is an issue with the CAN wiring. For example, if one or more device in the chain has the CANH and CANL wires flipped. However, your first point above should rule this out. It doesn’t hurt to check CAN wiring thoroughly once again.
